title: Johnson rejects UK election pact with Nigel Farage
text:
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson | Pool photo by Julian Simmonds/WPA Pool via Getty Images Johnson rejects UK election pact with Nigel Farage The Brexit Party has called on the Conservatives to stand down in dozens of seats.

NEW YORK — Boris Johnson flatly rejected an offer from Nigel Farage for a non-aggression pact between the Conservatives and the Brexit Party at a likely upcoming general election.

The prime minister said he would “of course” be fielding a candidate in every seat in the country and ruled out any form of alliance.

Farage has promised the Tories a clear run at its existing seats and all its targets if Johnson agrees to stand down in around 80 other constituencies and signs up to a no-deal Brexit policy.

But speaking to journalists as he flew to the U.N. General Assembly in New York, Johnson said: “The Conservative Party is the oldest, most successful political party in the world, and we will be contesting the next election when the opposition finally summon up the nerve to have an election. We will be contesting the next election as Conservatives and not in an alliance or a pact or a coupon procedure.”

Asked if his party would contest every seat in the country, he added: “Of course.”

He was also told that Farage said in a newspaper interview that the pair get on well, to which the prime minister replied: "God." He added: “I have personally good relations with all sorts of political opponents, which is one of the glories of British political culture."

Johnson tried to call an election earlier this month but opposition MPs blocked his bid in the House of Commons, saying they would not support it until the October 31 Brexit date had been delayed.

Polling suggests the Conservatives could be at risk in an election if the Brexit Party syphons off some of its vote while the pro-Remain parties club together to avoid splitting their support in anti-Brexit seats.

The Brexit Party hopes to win big in northern seats held by the opposition Labour Party, which voted for Brexit in large numbers at the 2016 EU referendum.

Farage made a plea to Johnson earlier this month, saying: “If you have the courage for a clean-break Brexit, then we will help you secure a big Brexit majority. Together we can destroy [Jeremy] Corbyn’s Labour.”
